ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: My knowledge of the German language grew immensely this semester. Coming in knowing nothing, the class is fast-paced but very engaging and facilitates learning German vocabulary and grammar structure very well. My conversational German grew a lot, but I think the class definitely helped me in my reading and writing of German. Having a native speaker, it was also interesting to talk a bit about culture.
I learned German verb tenses, sentence structures, and vocabulary.
Ability to learn a language, different mode of learning

I gained a very solid understanding of some basics of the German language, including everyday vocabulary, present and perfect active verb conjugations, modal verbs with infinitives, and case uses. I also have developed some pretty good instincts about the language, things which are hard to articulate or recognize consciously but which make conversation and comprehension a lot easier.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class was great in facilitating fast learning. With the class being conducted in German, it was sometimes a bit daunting, but it was very helpful in the overall learning process. The class breaks students out of their comfort zone with regards to speaking, allowing them to really challenge themselves and in the long run learn a lot. The asynchronous assignments were not as engaging, but they definitely were helpful in getting a full German education in speaking, reading, writing, and listening. Sometimes, the organization of the class and the class Canvas page made it a little bit challenging to understand assignments and tasks.

Strengths: Small class size, good variety of assignments, pacing
Weaknesses: some technical errors with Canvas exams that interfered with me completing the test to the best of my ability
Very communicative and collaborative, immersive environment. Sometimes the set up and scheduling of the required content was confusing
The course is well planned and versatile.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think that this course adapted wonderfully to the virtual format! The discussion-style sections replicated the normal language experience, enriched with the asynchronous assignments that allowed for a bit of flexibility this semester.
I liked the weekend assignments, and as someone who enjoys reading and practicing the language on my own, I liked the mix of synchronous and asynchronous days.

The online course format could be improved in terms of knowing where all the content is. Also from an international student perspective only having one course time was very difficult and wasn't very accessible or flexible for students working across different time zones.

I found the model of the course extremely successful. The wide range of assignment formats (video submissions, worksheets, Canvas quizzes, online homework assignments) provided variety and allowed me to learn in a lot of different ways. I found the balance of synchronous and asynchronous learning to be helpful, too, although I would prefer a return to a full week of synchronous classes once in-person classes are possible again.

Most of the practices worked really well and were useful, but the zoom seminar content could be improved. Also there were a lot of times that we had technical issues when accessing some of the homework.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! I learned more in this semester of German than in years of language courses in high school. It was super engaging, and it's a fun language!

Definitely! I did not know any German coming into 110, which was scary but has made the class super rewarding! The first week was a little intense, but overall the class is paced really well for new German students (not so slow that its boring but not so fast that you miss entire concepts and feel that you have to spend the whole time catching up). If you are undecided about how to get your foreign language requirement done, take German!
Yes, the course was engaging and a good challenge but also paced well and allowed for collaboration
Yes. If you want to learn German this is an excellent way to do it. I wish I had taken the intensive intro sequence, but this course gave me plenty of challenge and a great basis for future learning.
Yes, I would. I benefited a lot from this course.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Met three times per week as seminar-style course, with the other two days consisting of asynchronous assignments.
We alternated between live virtual discussions and asynchronous assignment days.
Three virtual seminars and two asynchronous learning days per week; asynchronous days included short recorded lectures, readings, and homework submitted in various formats online.
Group activities and asynchronous lectures.
